    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2018/02/16/andromeda_galaxy_milky_way/</id>
    <updated>2018-02-16T06:11:11Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>Katyanna Quach</name>
      <uri>https://search.theregister.co.uk/?author=Katyanna%20Quach</uri>
    </author>
    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2018/02/16/andromeda_galaxy_milky_way/"/>
    <title type="html">Astro-boffinry world rocked to its very core: Shock as Andromeda found to be not much bigger than Milky Way</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Everything we knew was a lie</h4> <p>The Andromeda galaxy is actually roughly the same size as the Milky Way, and may not engulf our galaxy when it is expected to collide in about four billion years time, according to new research.…</p></summary>
  </entry>

    <title type="html">Arrrgh! Put down the crisps! 'Ultra-processed' foods linked to cancer!</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Just kidding – vague definitions, confounding factors mean you probably shouldn't panic... yet</h4> <p>A study has suggested a link between diets high in ultra-processed foods and an increased risk of cancer – but academics have warned against over-interpreting the results.…</p> <p><!--#include virtual='/data_centre/_whitepaper_textlinks_top.html' --></p></summary>

  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2018/02/15/geeks_guide_to_britain_porthcurno/</id>
    <updated>2018-02-15T09:05:07Z</updated>
    <author>
      <name>SA Mathieson</name>
      <uri>https://search.theregister.co.uk/?author=SA%20Mathieson</uri>
    </author>
    <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://go.theregister.com/feed/www.theregister.co.uk/2018/02/15/geeks_guide_to_britain_porthcurno/"/>
    <title type="html">Life's a beach – then you're the comms nexus of the British Empire and Marconi-baiting hax0rs</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Inside Porthcurno's world-spanning telegraphy web</h4> <p><strong>Geek's Guide to Britain</strong>  I'm sitting on a perfect sandy beach in dazzling winter sunshine which makes it feel two months warmer than it really is. The beach is nearly empty, although a couple of dogs are enjoying the surf. The nearest road peters out a few hundred yards up a steep valley – the only way here is to walk. Porthcurno beach, just a few miles from Land's End in Cornwall, feels pleasantly like it is a long way from anywhere.…</p></summary>
  </entry>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Astroboffins calculate MuskMobile will only last millions of years, has decent chance of bonking Earth, Venus</h4> <p>Explaining why he used his Tesla roadster as the test mass on his Falcon Heavy launch, Elon Musk remarked that he liked the idea of it orbiting for a billion years.…</p></summary>

    <title type="html">NASA budget shock: Climate studies? GTFO. We're making the Moon great again, says Trump</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Cheer up – by 2030, we'll have flying cars, too</h4> <p>President Trump's administration has handed down a budget for 2019 to NASA – and it effectively kills off key projects in exchange for a vague promise to go back to the Moon.…</p> <p><!--#include virtual='/data_centre/_whitepaper_textlinks_top.html' --></p></summary>

    <title type="html">What did we say about Tesla's self-driving tech? SpaceX Roadster skips Mars, steers to asteroids</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Where's a sat-nav when you need one?</h4> <p><strong>Pic</strong>  The final rocket burn of the SpaceX craft carrying Elon Musk's personal Tesla Roadster into the cosmos pushed the billionaire's flash jalopy much further than anticipated. It's now heading out toward the Solar System's asteroid belt rather than swinging close by Mars as planned.…</p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Better-than-expected performance created 'the quietest place in space'</h4> <p>In <i>other</i> space news today, the boffins in charge of the European Space Agency's LISA Pathfinder mission have wrapped up the final results for the space-based gravitational wave dry run.…</p></summary>

  <entry>

    <title type="html">Can't wait to get to Mars on a SpaceX ship? It's a cold, dead rock – boffins</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4><i>El Reg</i> says: Ignore the Big Red Planet lobby, get your ASCII to somewhere better</h4> <p>SpaceX <a target="_blank" href="https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/02/06/spacex_falcon_heavy_launch/">today parked</a> Elon Musk's Tesla Roadster in Earth's orbit, using a Falcon Heavy lifter, with a rocket strapped to the flash motor to take it on to Mars.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>

    <title type="html">MY GOD, IT'S FULL OF CARS: SpaceX parks a Tesla in orbit (just don't mention the barge)</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Falcon Heavy blasts off, 2 boosters return, 1 destroyed</h4> <p><strong>Video</strong>  After <a target="_blank" href="https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/01/08/spacex_falcon_heavy_testing/">years of setbacks</a>, SpaceX today successfully launched its Falcon Heavy three-in-one rocket and delivered into orbit its cherry-red payload – Elon Musk's very own Tesla Roadster.…</p></summary>

  <entry>
    <id>tag:theregister.co.uk,2005:story/2018/02/06/nasa_image_satellite_update_battery_is_full_satellite_working/</id>

    <title type="html">NASA's zombie IMAGE satellite is powered up and working quite nicely</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Sat's battery is full and stuff thought to be broken in 2005 is working again</h4> <p>NASA has updated the status of its once-was-lost, now-is-found IMAGE satellite and revealed the bird's power supplies are operational. The space agency will therefore attempt to revive the mission – if it can find money to fund the effort.…</p> <p><!--#include virtual='/data_centre/_whitepaper_textlinks_top.html' --></p></summary>
  </entry>
  <entry>

    <title type="html">Women beat men to jobs due to guys' bad social skills. Whoa – you mad, fellas? Maybe these eggheads have a point...</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>The future is female – or at least female friendly</h4> <p>While the world worries about savvy computers taking people's jobs, it may want to focus more on how to retrain its men, who are evidently ill-equipped for work that's increasingly social.…</p></summary>
  </entry>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>'Mad' Mike living up to his nickname</h4> <p><strong>Video</strong>  An American bloke, who reckons Earth is flat as a frisbee, is on a quest to send himself into space to verify his theory. And on Sunday, he failed to even launch a rocket to a few hundred feet.…</p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Gravitational microlensing helps astroboffins spot planets 3.8 BEELLION light-years away</h4> <p>The Kepler Space Telescope has found oodles of exoplants, but now astroboffins have spotted the first exoplanets outside our galaxy.…</p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>They had one job during the record eight-hour EVA ...</h4> <p>A record-breaking spacewalk conducted over the weekend ended with an antenna pointed in the wrong direction on the International Space Station (ISS).…</p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Galaxies merged together house the greediest voids</h4> <p>Supermassive black holes in merger galaxies snack on one star every year, according to a paper published on Thursday.…</p> <p><!--#include virtual='/data_centre/_whitepaper_textlinks_top.html' --></p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Bonus space news: wanna salvage a SpaceX Falcon 9?</h4> <p>Demonstrating again that anti-missile missiles work best under carefully controlled circumstances, a test of such a weapon fired from Hawaii has missed its target.…</p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Vanished IMAGE now found. Don't suppose anyone kept a copy of its comms code?</h4> <p>NASA has announced it will try to wake up the “zombie satellite” IMAGE, unexpectedly found working by an amateur sat-spotter.…</p></summary>

    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>NASA reckons it might even be able to operate 'IMAGE', thought dead since 2005</h4> <p>An amateur astronomer hunting the <a target="_blank" href="https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/01/08/spacex_delivers_classified_zuma/">Zuma satellite that SpaceX may or may not have lost</a> has instead turned up signals from a NASA bird thought dead since 2005.…</p></summary>

  <entry>

    <title type="html">GOLD! Always believe in your role. You've got the power to know you're indestructible...</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Always believe in... because you are GOLD</h4> <p>NASA’s Global-scale Observations of the Limb and Disk (<a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" href="https://www.nasa.gov/content/goddard/gold">GOLD</a>) instrument is successfully heading into orbit – after the Ariane 5 rocket lifting it into space worryingly lost its radio link with Earth.…</p></summary>
  </entry>

    <title type="html">RIP John Young: NASA's longest-serving 'naut explores final frontier</title>
    <summary type="html" xml:base="http://www.theregister.co.uk/"><h4>Spacefaring veteran flew into space six times, once with a corned beef sarnie</h4> <p><strong>Obit</strong>  John Young, the first pilot of a space shuttle, and longest serving astronaut in NASA's history, has died at the age of 87 due to complications caused by pneumonia.…</p></summary>
  </entry>
